item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment.
Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

item.name: Federal aid to water resources development

summary.text: Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Recreation Authorization Act - Directs the Secretary of the Army, with the consent of appropriate local and state entities, to enter into arrangements, contracts, and leases with public, private, and nonprofit entities to: (1) evaluate, construct, operate, and maintain capital improvements for recreational use of the Intracoastal Waterway, Delaware River to Chesapeake Bay, Delaware and Maryland (Chesapeake and Delaware Canal) and its related facilities; and (2) provide security for the canal and such facilities. Sets the federal share of the cost of capital improvements at 50% and of operation and maintenance costs at 100%. Directs the Secretary to credit toward the non-federal share of project costs design and construction work carried out by the non-federal interest before the date of an agreement if such work is integral to the project.

bill.title: Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Recreation Authorization Act

item.title: Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Recreation Authorization Act

To authorize the Secretary of the Army to evaluate, construct, operate, and maintain capital improvements to the Intracoastal Waterway, Delaware River to Chesapeake Bay, Delaware and Maryland (Chesapeake and Delaware Canal) for public recreation.
Chesapeake and Delaware Canal Recreation Authorization Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
